Key Match Events: Trea Turner was a triple shy of the cycle.
Johan Rojas added a career-high three doubles.
Kody Clemens also had three hits.
Philadelphia Phillies had season highs for runs and hits, with 22.
Zack Wheeler threw six innings of one-run ball, allowed two hits, and struck out seven.
Philadelphia Phillies scored seven runs over the first two innings.
Trea Turner had a two-run homer in a four-run second inning.
J.T. Realmuto singled twice and had two RBI before leaving in the fourth due to a left knee contusion.
Otto López hit a run-scoring double in the fourth for Miami Marlins.
Philadelphia Phillies increased their advantage to double figures with three runs in the fifth and four in the sixth.
Kyle Schwarber hit a 434-foot drive to right-center in the sixth.
Pre-Game Insights: Edward Cabrera, the original starter for Miami, was a late scratch because of migraine-like symptoms.
Marlins manager Skip Schumaker learned Cabrera couldn't pitch 90 minutes before the game.
Retired Marlins outfielder Jeff Conine threw the ceremonial first pitch to son Griffin, whom Miami promoted from Triple-A on Aug. 26 and started in right-field Friday.
Post-Match Reflections: Zack Wheeler commented on the difficulty of such games but appreciated the run support.
Johan Rojas emphasized the importance of winning and competing.
Trea Turner highlighted the team's relentless and competitive spirit.
Phillies manager Rob Thomson praised the team's offensive performance.
Marlins manager Skip Schumaker reflected on the tough spot for their bullpen and the need to adjust.
Miscellaneous Highlights: Marlins outfielder David Hensley pitched the last two innings and allowed two runs in the ninth.
Phillies placed 3B Alec Bohm on the 10-day injured list and recalled infielder Buddy Kennedy from Triple-A Lehigh Valley.
